context: VOCs were detected at trace levels (few ngm−3) and LODs obtained were clearly below legislated levels. So, it can be concluded that VERAM samplers are suitable tools to evaluate the air quality in the studied places and that the studied places are in good agreement with the mean tolerated threshold limit values of the time weighted average concentration of VOCs. Numerous laboratory tests have shown that, on an equal mass basis, nanoscale zero valent iron (NZVI) alone, NZVI doped with a catalyst metallic component such as palladium, and surface-modified NZVI such as iron–carbon composites all exhibit greater reductive dechlorination rates for chlorinated hydrocarbons than does granular iron and their use may represent a promising approach for in situ contaminant treatment (Wang and Zhang, 1997; Lien and Zhang, 1999; Zhang, 2003; Liu et al., 2005a,b; 2007; Song and Carraway, 2005, 2006; He and Zhao, 2005; Li et al., 2006; He et al., 2007, 2009; Otto et al., 2008; Cho and Choi, 2010; Zhan et al., 2011). Consequently, there has been increasing interest in field applications of various NZVI materials to remediate groundwater resources contaminated with chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) such as tetrachloroethene (PCE) and trichloroethene (TCE) (Elliott and Zhang, 2001; Quinn et al., 2005; O'Hara et al., 2006; Wei et al., 2010; He et al., 2010). Because NZVI particles are ferromagnetic they tend to aggregate in suspension (Schrick et al., 2004; Nurmi et al., 2005; Phenrat et al., 2007) making them difficult to inject, which inhibits their field application (Hotze et al., 2010). Recent research efforts have been made both in laboratory and field tests to increase NZVI colloidal stability by modifying NZVI surfaces with polymers thereby increasing their mobility in the subsurface once injected (Henn and Waddill, 2006; Vecchia et al., 2009; Phenrat et al., 2010a,b, 2011; Bennett et al., 2010; He et al., 2010; Sunkara et al., 2010; Zhan et al., 2011). Yet, detailed field tests are scarce that have evaluated changes in both contaminant concentration and mass flux over time.
